Not necessarily. As someone who develops tech products, I can tell you after numerous tests, account sign up before value is provided yields higher metrics for both us and for the users. It's backed up by some psychological research about people valuing something a lot more if even a tiny amount of work is required to get it.

On one product I worked on, when we tested requiring account creation first, user engagement went up 50% and revenue went up 15%, along with a whole host of secondary metrics that also increased.

Like most things on LPT, this isn't true at all.

As a business that offers a subscription service, your goal is to get as many people signed up as possible. If you can get people to sign up before viewing something, you take advantage of it.

It's not that a company should be thinking "let's let them sample and we'll prove to them that we're worth it".

 It's about doing anything they can to can to drive more customers. They obviously hope you'll stick around after viewing the content, but their customer base will be much much smaller if they let you view their content without signing up.

I guess it depends because I constantly have been getting 10-25% off on most of my orders by providing my spam email to them. If the site is really shady I won’t even put in my spam email until I find something I need. Then I just go back to the website with a new vpn provided IP and put it my spam address for the new user code or to activate the website script for applying discounts into the cart.

I’ve saved thousands by entering my spam email into websites over the past few years. Everything that is in my Amazon cart that is expensive, high quality, or foodstuffs gets cross checked with the manufacturer website to see if I can get better deals and I usually do. (I’d never buy foodstuffs from Amazon unless it came directly from whole foods) The only websites I avoid are the ones that absolutely need your phone number and a confirmation and most of those if you look carefully are only asking for your number but not requiring it for the code. They don’t explicitly say that (scammy, I know) but it’s usually in the small black print or hidden in the phrasing that you don’t actually need to provide your phone number for the code/discount.

Most very reputable US based websites that represent companies that manufacture in the US do this. Actually most reputable websites with high quality goods and have a reputation they want to grow in general do this, so don’t think it’s only shady websites that do this. It’s just good for business.
Same for giving them your email phone name address etc. they are trying to get you invested. Homeadvisor etc. f that. Abandon. Don’t get invested because you told them your decks square footage.
